The article criticizes the fact that some schools use aid money - likely merit aid money - to attract bright students who may not have a lot of financial aid.

The reality is more complicated since that very practice may increase the aid available for high need students. Here's why.

At most private colleges and universities tuition revenue is the source of most the money that runs the school. Tuition revenue from those able to pay is also the source of most of the financial aid.

It is a sort of "Robin Hood" system. You need to charge some students (or their parents) a lot more than the actual cost of providing instruction, so that you can charge others a lot less.

Thus how much aid any given school can afford, depends on how much tuition it gets from others paying above actual cost.

Leaving aside room and board, lets say the cost of providing instruction is $20K and the "sticker price" for tuition is $35K.

Then anyone paying above $20K is making a net contribution to financial aid. If 5 merit scholarship at $5K are given to high achievers with little need, they will pay $30K each for a net over and above cost of $50k that can be used to provide financial aid to those who can less than 20K.

If actual cost is $20K, 2 students paying $30K can cover the cost of one paying $0.

You get some really talented students AND you end up with more financial aid to support high need students.

Yes, Mark, FDR's catchy motto is oft-quoted; but it's rarely remembered that all the "methods" he tried failed at getting us out of the Great Depression, and that we had to wait for the production demands of a global war to do that. One might argue that his last "method", massive debt to fund those production demands, finally worked, but one could as easily thank Hitler, Mussolini and Tojo for that as FDR.

A perfect pairing of FDR quotes, the "how" ("try something") of making it better, and the "why" (being a decent and compassionate society).

Unfortunately we are saddled with a Congress full of "I don't care" Honey Badger elected officials who were sent there by ignorant, distracted Honey Boo Boo voters. "Do Nothing Congress" actually describes a higher level of motivation and productivity than the current group exhibits. One–exactly one– committee member shows up for a hearing on unemployment, while Issa conducts a three-ring media circus over a tragic but historically meaningless overseas incident characterized by him and his as the result of dereliction tantamount to treason.

What the Republicans are doing IS treason, the deliberate sabotage of responsive government in times of great need and suffering.

Fiscal stimulus is necessary but not sufficient. When there is lack of demand in its economy, If a government will not spend to provide demand, the nation will suffer. But just spending is not enough.

What to spend it on? FDR provided the answer to that, "It is common sense to take a method and try it. If it fails, admit it frankly and try another. But above all, try something."

Government need not be perfect and have all the answers, which is a good thing, because none are perfect nor do any have all the answers. All that is required is that they try, and keep trying.

For a guide, FDR gives another, "The test of our progress is not whether we add more to the abundance of those who have much it is whether we provide enough for those who have little."

As I understand it, Congress did deny State the funding necessary to protect the Benghazi outpost to the extent necessary. When we worked in Tripoli in 1972-73, my wife and I always found Benghazi a much more pleasant, relaxed place to be--almost a separate country. After the downfall of the Libyan Revolutionary Command Council, we should have known that the two halves of the country would split even further, and should either have given better security to the Benghazi facility or closed it altogether, in light of the Congress's unwillingness to fund it adequately.

While much of the Benghazi story - who knew what and when, who edited the talking points and why - doesn't pass the smell test, the real crux of the problem is whether or not the US government provides adequate security for diplomats stationed in unstable countries. This must be analyzed and corrected with a sense of urgency. Did Congress cut funding to the State Department to such a degree that we simply do not have the money we need to protect our own people abroad?  And if so - who should be help responsible for that?
